project_overview.summary: "Invisible Lamppost" is an interactive prototype project supported by the East Cultural Centre. It utilises a 3D and real-time tracking system to explore the possibility of speculative reality.

featured_image_with_text.content: The primary objective of this project is to delve into various techniques and strategies that can be employed to evoke a sense of spatial presence in theatrical performances. It seeks to ignite the audience's imagination by incorporating virtual props that enhance the overall immersive experience on stage.

featured_text_1.content: The purpose of this project is to explore possibilities to provoke a sense of space on stage and the imagination of virtual props.

subtitle_and_body_1.subtitle: Part I: puzzle-solving narrative
subtitle_and_body_1.body: The narrative revolves around a security guard patrolling a building and solving problems for residents. The experience is formed by a series of movements and projecting silhouettes. To solve the puzzle, participants need to find specific angles and positions and project meaningful silhouettes on the wall to proceed.

highlighted_content_with_gallery_1.title: Part II: puzzle-solving narrative
highlighted_content_with_gallery_1.content: The second part consists of the "corridors" connecting one "room" to another. Participants need to reach a goal by making their way across the stage and "checking in". In contrast to the free exploration experience in the "rooms", this part includes a specific patrol route that participants need to follow and perform actions as instructed.

highlighted_content_with_gallery_2.title: Process
highlighted_content_with_gallery_2.content:
A 3D virtual space is constructed and synchronized with the physical space on stage. Virtual objects built in the 3D environment are visualized as silhouette projections in the physical space through the use of a tracking device, a "torch," that casts light onto the stage walls.

During the creation of this prototype, ioio gained experience in utilizing stage tracking software and acquired a new workflow for experimental and theatrical projects. The project is open to further development and collaboration, showcasing the potential for technological innovation in the realm of theater and performance.
